~ Cole and Ohanian (1999, Table 6) find total factor productivity to fall five percent in the first year of the Great Depression, and a total of 14 percent through four years. Mulligan (2005, Figure 4) finds the Great Depression labor supply distortion to increase 0.17 log points in the first year and 0.46 log points through four years. In other words, 1929-30 would be in the same quadrant of Figure 15 as the 1970s recession, and on about the same ray from the origin, but five times further away.
